The condensate stabilizer receives hydrocarbon liquids from a number of sources, mainly from the plant inlet separation, debutanizer bottoms (as described above) and from the Y-Grade system that is further described below.  There are other small sources including various heavy hydrocarbon dumps in the plant.   The condensate stabilizer treats the liquid to form a stable crude oil product that can be stored in low pressure storage tanks.  This is achieved through a trayed column with the application of heat in a reboiler provided by the plants hot oil system.  Lighter components are removed and combined with the separated inlet gas for processing.  The stabilized bottoms product is cooled and routed to two, low-pressure condensate storage tanks.  Liquids from the storage tanks are shipped offsite to sales via truck.  The condensate tanks are equipped with gas blanketing and vapors are captured and compressed via a vapor recovery unit and routed to the plants fuel system.  
The facility receives Y-Grade product from various producers that deliver product to the facility via truck.  The y-grade is a mixture of natural gas liquids containing ethane, propane, butanes, pentanes, hexanes and heavier components.  The product is offloaded from tanker trucks via a truck unloading station. Third party trucks will offload y-grade utilizing their hoses and onboard pumps.  The product is stored in the Y-grade storage tank and then routed to the condensate stabilizer to be treated as described above.  
The facilitys process contains threshold quantities of regulated flammable substances including methane, ethane, propane, i-butane, n-butane, i-pentane, and n-pentane.

These are described in more detail below:
Flammable Worst-Case Scenario  
This involves a hypothetical catastrophic failure of a single condensate storage tank.  The two condensate storage tanks are the facilitys largest hydrocarbon storage vessels.  These tanks contain greater than threshold quantities of regulated flammable mixtures containing Methane, Ethane, Propane, i-Butane, n-Butane, i-Pentane, and n-Pentane.  The majority of the fluid in the tanks is unregulated hexanes+.  However, all the contents of the tank are allocated on a mass weighted average basis back to the regulated flammable substances for the worst-case scenario evaluation.  This estimation is conservative and is required under § 68.115(b)(2).  This scenario assumes the tank is 100% full and assumes failure of applicable safeguards.  The worst-case flammable release distance to endpoint was determined using EPAs RMP*Comp.  The distance to the 1psi overpressure endpoint is 1.1 miles.  There are a number of public receptors within this distance including 67 Residences with an estimated residential population of 201.

HATTERS POND GAS PLANT
RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

OVERALL FACILITY DESCRIPTION
Hatter's Pond Plant is located 20 miles north of Mobile, Alabama.  It is situated on a 30-acre plot west of Creola, Alabama in Mobile County, 1340 Radcliff Road in Section 10, Township 2S, Range 1W.  
The plant is fed by a number of natural gas wells that deliver gas to the plant inlet.  The gas goes through separation, amine treating, dehydration, NGL extraction, and compression for eventual delivery to a sales gas pipeline.  Extracted natural gas liquids are further processed through fractionation to produce marketable propane and butane that are sold and transferred to transport trucks at the facility.  Natural gas condensate from plant inlet separation is stabilized and stored in condensate tanks and transferred to transport trucks for sales.   The facility also receives Y-Grade product from various sources via transport trucks which is loaded into a Y-Grade storage tank and injected into the condensate stream where it is stabilized and stored along with the natural gas condensate.  A peripheral gas field also delivers natural gas to the facility, and this gas is treated, dehydrated, and processed through a JT skid to extract liquids.  The remaining peripheral gas is only used as fuel for the facility as the nitrogen content makes it non-marketable to the downstream pipeline.  The extracted natural gas liquids from this peripheral gas stream are sent to the main inlet separation where remaining liquids are stabilized and stored along with the main feeds natural gas condensate.   
Process heat for the facility is provided through the use of two, natural gas fired, hot oil heaters.  Hot oil is used for amine regeneration, fractionation, condensate stabilization, and glycol regeneration.  Refrigeration used for liquids extraction is accomplished through a propane refrigeration system.
The facility is required to implement a Risk Management Program due to the type and quantities of chemica

ls that are located on site.   The RMP regulated chemicals onsite are methane, ethane, propane, iso-butane, butane, iso-pentane, and pentane.  Although small amounts of hydrogen sulfide are present in the in the gas streams feeding the plant, it exists in a small quantity that it is below threshold quantities per 40 CFR 68.130.  
The facility is subject to OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and is an EPA RMP Program 3 Facility.   
PROCESS DESCRIPTION  GAS PROCESSING
The Hatters Pond plant takes raw natural gas from the Hilcorp operated Hatters Pond and Chunchula fields where the gas undergoes a series of processes to deliver marketable natural gas, natural gas condensate, propane, and butane to market.  Threshold quantities of regulated flammable substances are present at the facility, but no threshold quantities of regulated toxic substances are present at the facility.  
The Hatters Pond field gas enters the plant at approximately 50psig, then undergoes separation and is compressed to approximately 185 psig.  The gas flows through a DGA (Diglycolaamine) amine unit that removes CO2 and H2S from the gas stream.  Rich amine from the DGA contactor is flashed in a flash vessel and the flash gas is sent to the plants fuel system to be used as fuel for various fired processes in the facility. The rich amine liquid flows to the DGA regeneration unit where the CO2 and H2S are driven off with heat from the facilitys hot oil system, creating a lean DGA stream.   The CO2 and H2S acid gas is incinerated in a thermal oxidizer.  The lean DGA is cooled and sent back to the amine contactor to restart the cycle.  
The treated, wet gas stream from the DGA contactor is further compressed to approximately 900 psig and then dehydrated in a triethylene glycol contact tower to meet pipeline water content specification and to avoid freezing in the gas chiller.  The dry gas is then sent to a Gas Chiller where it is cooled to a design temperature of -20 deg. F for hydrocarbo

n liquid (NGL) recovery and to meet gas pipeline specifications.  The cold, dry gas leaves the chiller and enters the Cold Separator where liquid hydrocarbons (NGLs) and the dry gas are separated.  The treated, dry gas is then delivered to a downstream pipeline for gas lift and sales.  Process cooling in the chiller is achieved through a propane refrigeration system.  
The separated natural gas liquids are then routed to a fractionation train consisting of one deethanizer, one depropanizer, and one debutanizer.  These are a series of trayed columns for separation of the mixed NGL product into constituent products - Ethane, Propane, Butane, and Natural Gasoline.  The deethanizer overhead product is sent to the plant sales line.   The deethanizer bottoms are routed to the depropanizer.  The depropanizer bottoms are routed to the debutanizer.  The resultant propane and butane products are cooled and stored in pressurized storage tanks and shipped offsite to sales via truck.  The propane and butane tanks are pressurized with pressure control being routed to flare.  The debutanizer bottoms product is produced as natural gasoline and is routed to the condensate stabilizer as described below.  
The facility also receives a portion of its natural gas feed from the Chunchula field.  This gas is similarly treated in a DGA contactor that shares a common regeneration system as described above.  The treated gas is dehydrated via triethylene glycol and routed to a Joule-Thompson system (JT skid) where the gas undergoes a series of pressure drops and heat exchanges to extract natural gas liquids.  The JT skid is self-contained and requires no process heat or cooling (hot oil or refrigeration) and contains no rotating machinery (such as pumps, compressors, etc.).  These resultant liquids are sent back to the plants inlet separation, where remaining liquids (after a pressure drop) are routed to the plants condensate stabilizer and stored in the condensate storage tanks. PREVENTION PROGRAMS  
The Hatters Pond facility is covered by OSHAs Process Safety Management standard and as such the facility has developed a comprehensive accidental release prevention program based on the elements of OSHA's PSM.  
The facility employs safety features to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances.  Such features include: (1) hydrocarbon/hydrogen sulfide detectors with audible and visual alarms, (2) pressure and process relief valves that discharge into the plant flare system, (3) automated and manual valves to permit isolation of plant process equipment, (4) plant and compressor station emergency shutdowns, (5) fire and smoke detection systems with audible and visual alarms, (6) curbing and/or diking to contain liquid releases, (7) redundant equipment and instrumentation such as uninterruptible power supply for process control and safety systems. 
Summarized below are brief descriptions of each part of the prevention program along with details of the emergency response program.  
Employee Participation
All employees and contractors at the Hatters Pond facility are involved and participate in all aspects of Process Safety Management and accident prevention.  Examples of Employee Participation include:
	Implementing Hilcorp policies and procedures concerning employee and public safety and environmental protection. 
	Preparing and/or updating technical documents such as operating and maintenance procedures.
	Working in accordance with standard operating procedures and safe work practices.
	Participating in safety meetings.
	Participating in training.
	Participating in the Management of Change (MOC) process.
	Participating in the Process Safety Management (PSM) audit process or a Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) Team


Participating in Incident Investigations
Employees have access to information pertaining to the PSM and RMP programs, and every employee is responsible for complying with all aspects of these programs. 
Process Safety Information
Hatters Pond maintains a variety of documents to ensure that process hazards are understood, and that the facility is operated and maintained in a safe manner. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  
Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDSs). The SDSs include information on the toxicity, permissible exposure limits, physical data, reactivity, corrosivity, thermal and chemical stability of the produced and processed materials and chemicals used in the facility.
Hatters Pond maintains documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.   Equipment specifications and vendor manufacturing information are used for equipment and system designs. The facility maintains information on materials of construction, piping and instrumentation diagrams, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.
For specific process areas, the facility has documented safety-related upper and lower process limits for specific process parameters (e.g., pressure, temperature, level, etc.) in the operating procedures for each process unit. The facility ensures that the process is maintained within these limits by using process controls and monitoring instruments

, operating procedures, trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).
Process Hazard Analysis
The facility has a comprehensive PHA program to help ensure that hazards associated with processes are identified and controlled.  PHAs are performed on an established schedule for PSM RMP processes.  PHA teams consist of experienced and qualified operations and maintenance personnel, engineering, and qualified facilitators.  The analysis is conducted in accordance with regulatory requirements and generally accepted industry standards.  The PHA requirement is met by the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) Studies conducted at the facility.
The PHA team recommendations are forwarded to facility management for resolution. The recommendations are then prioritized and implemented accordingly.  Implementation of safety improvements in response to PHA findings is completed in a timely manner. All approved safety improvements being implemented in response to PHA team recommendations are tracked until to completion. The final resolution of each recommendation is documented and retained by the facility Environmental, Health, and Safety Specialist.
The facility conducts revalidations of the PHAs at least every five years, as required by the PSM and RMP regulations, and incorporates changes in the process and previous incident evaluations into the revalidations.  Recommendations from the PHA revalidations are similarly documented and tracked to closure.  
Operating Procedures
The facility maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) initial startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) start-up following a turnaround or emergency shut-down. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators and refresher training for experienced operators. Procedures are perio

dically reviewed and annually certified by the Operations Supervisor as current and accurate. Procedures are maintained current by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made to the process.
In addition, the operating procedures discuss consequences of deviating from the safe limits and provide guidance on how to respond to events that result in exceeding safe operating limits for specific process or equipment parameters. The written operating procedures are readily available to operators in the process units and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks. Changes to operating procedures are tracked through the management of change (MOC) process.
Training
The facility employs a training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New employees receive initial basic training in facility operations.  After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests, skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently.  In addition, operators periodically receive ongoing refresher training and refresher courses on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level and to continually enhance the capabilities of the employees. This refresher training is conducted every three years. Refresher training on operating procedures is confirmed with a written test and walk-through of the process. All training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training
Mechanical Integrity
The Hatters Pond facility has established practices and procedures to maintain process equipment in a safe operating condition.  This mechanical integrity program includes pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, compressors, and emergency shutdown systems, among other items.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) Conducting tra

ining, (2) Developing written procedures, (3) Performing inspections and tests, (4) preventative maintenance (5) Correcting identified deficiencies, and (6) Applying quality assurance measures.  
Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels).  If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service or a management of change team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.  
Quality assurance measures are incorporated into equipment purchases and repairs.  This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that the proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.
Management of Change
Hatters Pond employs a system to manage changes to processes. Written procedures are in place to ensure that all process changes at the facility undergo appropriate reviews at the planning stage. The system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change. Systems are also in place to assure that communications of the changes will be made to all affected personnel before changes are implemented.  Affected chemical hazard information, process technology information, and equipment information, as well as procedures are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided with any necessary training on the change.
Pre-Startup Safety Reviews
Hatters Pond conducts a pre-startup

safety review for any systems that require a change in the process safety information (not required for replacement in kind). The purpose of the review is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service. This review provides additional checks to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. The review team uses checklists to verify aspects of readiness. A review involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function.
Compliance Audits
To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Hatters Pond conducts internal audits every three years to confirm the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.  The findings are forwarded to Hatters Pond management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked to completion.  The final resolution of each finding is documented.
Incident Investigation
The Hatters Pond facility promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and underlying cause(s) of the incident to develop corrective actions and implement steps to prevent a recurrence of the incident and prevent similar incidents.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent similar incidents, and forwards these results to management for further action. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked to completion.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (includin

g contractors) who could be affected.  Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years to be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.
Hot Work Permits and Safe Work Practices
The Hatters Pond facility's hot work program requires that detailed permitting activities take place before, during, and after any job that has the potential to provide a source of ignition. The hot work permit is followed through to completion of the work and permits are maintained onsite for a minimum of three years. The facility implements other work permits as necessary (such as Job Safety Analyses, Confined Space Entry, Lock-Out/Tag-Out) to assure safe work conditions present, maintained, and communicated.
Contractors
Hatters Pond uses contractors to supplement its work force and to perform project-specific activities.  Some contractors work on or near process equipment.  Therefore, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform facility personnel of any hazards that they find during the course of their work. 
The Hilcorp Contractor Management program outlines a means of evaluating contractor safety programs and performance prior to entering the facility to perform work.  
Contract employers are responsible for training their employees and to provide training documentation. Contractor empoyees are provided with (1) information about safety and health hazards, (2) emergency response plan requirements, (3) safe work practices, and (4) a work permit process (i.e., for hot work, confined space, etc.) prior to beginning work.  
It is the responsibility of the facility to (1) inform contract employers of potential hazards related to the work, (2) explain HILCORP's emergency action plan, and (3)

control contract employees' entrance and exit to and from the facility.
It is the responsibility of HILCORP to (1) evaluate contract employer's safety performance and programs, and (2) periodically evaluate contractor's safety performance and maintain an injury and illness log of the contractor's work at the facility.
It is the contract employer's responsibility to ensure that its employees are (1) trained in safe work practices of their job, (2) informed on potential hazards of the process and to their specific job, (3) aware that contact employees must inform a plant representative of potential hazards in the contractor's work.
Emergency Response Program
The Hatters Pond facility implements and maintains a written Emergency Response Plan to protect public health, worker health (both employees and contractors), and the environment; and to minimize any effects in the unlikely event of an emergency. The plan consists of procedures for responding to accidental releases and procedures for responding to fires in the event of a release of a flammable substance.  
The Emergency Response Plan address the following aspects of emergency response, and more:
	Informing emergency response agencies about an accidental release
	Informing the public about an accidental release that may adversely affected by an accidental release from the facility
	Proper first aid and medical treatment
	Measures for emergency response after an accidental release has occurred
	Evacuation routes and plans, including provisions for accounting for personnel (employees, contractors, and visitors) after an evacuation.
	Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.
Training is conducted to ensure the proper use of emergency response equipment, such as fire-fighting equipment.  Employees are assigned specific roles that they would fill in the event of an emergency, and all employees receive specific training to enable them to fulfill their roles in an emergency.  The incident response plan

is updated as necessary and reviewed annually. 
The emergency response plan is coordinated with Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee to review incident response plans and facilitate communications and planning.  The Hatters Pond facility has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department).  This provides a method for notifying the public in the event of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Hatters Pond facility conducts periodic emergency response drills and tabletop exercises that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations.
Trade Secrets
There are currently no processes at the facility that carry the Trade Secret label.
FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
In the past 5 years, there have been no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage as a result of activities or incidents at the Hatters Pond Facility.
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The Hatters Pond facility has programs in place to improve safety on a continuous basis. 
These programs include the following:
	Monthly safety meetings.
	Annual safety training
	Emergency response drills and tabletop exercises involving emergency response agencies. 
	Process Hazards Analysis revalidations.
	Management of change.
	Mechanical Integrity & Quality Assurance.
	Incident Investigations 
	Compliance audits.
